author: MunkyDrag0n

text:
I think that while Armstrong's ideals make sense, that we should all strive for what we believe in and not what we're told to believe in, I also think he takes it too far. He believes that only the strong should survive; that's the same logic that applied during the age of Social Darwinism, and that was a hellhole for people who lacked the ability to adapt.

In the end, Raiden follows through on fighting for his own cause but he doesn't end up hurting those he cares for in the process. He won.
author: MariktheGunslinger

text: Revengeance at once demonises Armstrong's cult of strength but acknowledges that Raiden wouldn't have won unless he was stronger - physically. The message seems to be 'might makes right' regardless of innocence or justice (child soldiers). Raiden doesn't say he's stronger because he believes in good - indeed, the Ripper enjoys straight-up murdering people. Morally speaking Revengeance is kinda grey, but the deciding factor is, as you said, empathy: Raiden has it, Armstrong hasn't.
author: Kaz

text: You are correct sir. Armstrong's ethos is basically 'strength is good, so everyone should be strong'. This sounds halfway decent, until you realise that Armstrong curiously forgets to mention what he thinks should happen to those who either can't or don't want to be strong. Raiden beats him at his own game so he isn't even mad when he dies: he can't imagine someone stronger than him genuinely wanting to *protect* the weak because strong people only respect strength, right?

text:
However, reports of my death were greatly exaggerated.

How did I survive?

You already know.  Two words.  Say it with me now:

Nanomachines, son.

Having gotten that out of the way...Okamii, I do appreciate how you defend me.  Your side is valid too.  Letit not be said though that George Sears wasn't a true hero, and patriot.  How many men would fight so hard, risk demonizing themselves to become an inspiration to men like me?
